headline.main: East Meets West, Adding Pounds and Peril

docs.lead_paragraph: Asians are acutely susceptible to diabetes, a factor that is compounded by recent immigrants' collision with American diet.
docs.snippet: Asians are acutely susceptible to diabetes, a factor that is compounded by recent immigrants' collision with American diet.

headline.main: In the Treatment of Diabetes, Success Often Does Not Pay

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors and hospitals profit by treating complications of diabetes but lose money when they try to prevent them.
docs.snippet: Doctors and hospitals profit by treating complications of diabetes but lose money when they try to prevent them.

headline.main: Living at an Epicenter of Diabetes, Defiance and Despair

docs.lead_paragraph: In East Harlem, an invisible web of diabetes stretches throughout the neighborhood, touching nearly every life with its menace.
docs.snippet: In East Harlem, an invisible web of diabetes stretches throughout the neighborhood, touching nearly every life with its menace.

docs.abstract: Evidence continues to mount supporting link between diabetes and heart disease; recent study published in New England Journal of Medicine holds that aggressively lowering person's blood sugar level can cut risk of heart attack and stroke almost in half; research shows that heart disease may precede symptoms of diabetes and experts agree that either condition should signal doctors to look for and treat other condition as well; treatment options discussed; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Lapiana had an ominous family history: both his parents had Type 2 diabetes, and both died of heart disease -- the most frequent cause of death in all forms of diabetes. Since his 20's, Mr. Lapiana has had hypertension, a danger signal for diabetes and for heart disease. But until he was 50, when he mentioned his unquenchable thirst -- a symptom of diabetes -- to a doctor, Mr. Lapiana had slipped under the medical radar. The doctor tested his blood sugar and found that his glucose was five times as high as the normal level.
docs.snippet: Doctors now have solid evidence that aggressively lowering a person's blood sugar level can cut the risk of heart attack and stroke nearly in half.

headline.sub: One Day in the Trenches ;As Cases Surge in New York, So Do Fears Of an Overburdened Medical System ;
headline.main: Diabetes and Its Awful Toll Quietly Emerge as a Crisis

docs.lead_paragraph: An estimated 800,000 adult New Yorkers now have diabetes, and city health officials describe the problem as an epidemic.
docs.snippet: An estimated 800,000 adult New Yorkers now have diabetes, and city health officials describe the problem as an epidemic.

headline.main: Diabetes and Its Awful Toll Quietly Emerge as a Crisis

docs.lead_paragraph: Begin on the sixth floor, third room from the end, swathed in fluorescence: a 60-year-old woman was having two toes sawed off. One floor up, corner room: a middle-aged man sprawled, recuperating from a kidney transplant. Next door: nerve damage. Eighth floor, first room to the left: stroke. Two doors down: more toes being removed. Next room: a flawed heart. As always, the beds at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx were filled with a universe of afflictions. In truth, these assorted burdens were all the work of a single illness: diabetes. Room after room, floor after floor, diabetes. On any given day, hospital officials say, nearly half the patients are there for some trouble precipitated by the disease.
docs.snippet: Begin on the sixth floor, third room from the end, swathed in fluorescence: a 60-year-old woman was having two toes sawed off. One floor up, corner room: a middle-aged man sprawled, recuperating from a kidney transplant. Next door: nerve damage....
